qas.question: How was it suggested that the IPCC avoid political problems?

answers.text: remove government oversight from its processes

context: In <b4_0>February 2010<b4_0/>, in response to controversies regarding claims in the Fourth Assessment Report, <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b6_0>five<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> climate scientists<b6_0/> – all contributing or lead IPCC report authors – wrote in <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>the journal <b5_0>Nature<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> calling for changes to the IPCC. They suggested a range of new organizational options, from tightening the selection of lead authors and contributors, to dumping it in favor of a small permanent body, or even <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>turning the whole climate science assessment process into <b8_0>a moderated "living" Wikipedia-IPCC<b8_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Other recommendations included that the panel employ a full-time staff and <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>remove government oversight<a3_1/> from its processes<a3_2/><a3_0/> to avoid <b7_0>political interference<b7_0/>.
